content:
I don't know what link you're referring to, but these steps work, assuming Windows:

BACKUP

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This will prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content: That does not look like a product officially supported by Thunderbird. Do you recall where you got it? All I can state is that using a backup tool other than from Thunderbird has no guarantees, and persons on the support forum will not be able to assist. From my experience, the only backup that works every time is one done using the OS's file management software.
creator: davidsk

content: I downloaded this from a website some years ago, assuming it was a recommended Mozilla backup product. I backed up my account then, but never had any reason to use it, and now that I have a new computer, it does not seem to work anymore, so I am glad I asked about it and will use the recommended OS.s file management software mentioned. Thanks for the advice.

content: You're welcome. Also, should you have problems in a restore, it's easier to get help because the issue is simpler to address. :)

content: One more thing: Thunderbird DOES have a backup and restore feature. It's at the tools>export menu. But it has proved unreliable and problem-prone and difficult to recover from it.

content:
This is how I've always done it (Windows). It preserves your whole existing setup.

Copy TB files from the old PC

- launch TB on the old PC

- go to TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

- click the Application Basics > Profile Folder 'Open Folder' button

- the profile folder will open

- navigate three levels up to the AppData\Roaming folder

- close TB

- copy the AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird folder to a flash drive

---

Skip to 'Paste the copied TB files to the new PC', as you already installed TB and created a profile.

Install and launch TB on the new PC, then start setting up the new profile.

- on the 'Set Up Your Existing Email Address' screen, enter name and email address only

- click the 'Configure manually' link

- scroll down and click 'Cancel'

- exit setup

- close TB

---

Paste the copied TB files to the new PC

- open the AppData\Roaming folder like you did above

- delete the Thunderbird folder, or copy it somewhere if you want to save it

- replace it with the Thunderbird folder from the flash drive

- launch TB
creator: siffemoz

content:
Hai lo stesso problema in Modalità risoluzione dei problemi? -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/modalita-risoluzione-problemi-thunderbird

Approssimativamente quanto è grande il tuo archivio di posta?

Più in generale, Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

content:
If you open the Inbox file in Notepad and if you can still see the messages which Thunderbird no longer displays in the thread pane, that means that those messages are marked as deleted with a X-Mozilla-Status: 0009 And as long as you don't compact the Inbox folder those messages cas still be recovered by changing the X-Mozilla-Status: to 0000 or 0001. Actually the easiest way to restore deleted messages is with the add-on "Undelete" https://www.ggbs.de/extensions/Undelete.html

The other question is why those messages disappeared from your Inbox folder. For me this issue looks like an erroneous retention policy. Do you use the same email account on another device or did you change your retention policy (Account Settings > Synchronisation & Storage > Disk Space)? Or R-click on Inbox > Properties > Retention policy ...

Also see this discussion https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1566083
creator: Mapenzi

content:
FOR EXISTING FOLDERS These steps may help: To set many *existing* folders, follow these steps: This must be done on an account by account basis.

  1. select table view - the icon just to right of 'quick filter' button above message list pane
  2. select a message folder and apply all desired attributes - View>sort by from menu bar (if not shown, click alt key)
  3. click the icon at right side of column display in message list pane
  4. select the entry near bottom 'Apply current view to...'
  5. highlight 'folder and children'
  6. move mouse left to see account name and move left again to display all account folders. Now CLICK. a small menu will appear to confirm setting all folders within that account.

I did a simple (okay, crude) video at https://davidkirk.org/SettingDefaultFolderView.mp4
creator: davidsk

content:
After using normail uninstall tool from operating system, the profile folder is still there.

  1. from windows desktop, enter %appdata% in search box and press enter
  2. that should take you to the appdata\roaming folder. Delete the Thunderbird folder. There may also be a Thunderbird folder at appdata\Local. Delete that one as well.

The above steps assume user installed from thunderbird.net
creator: davidsk
